flow.context: Chris Longden is Director of Operations for East Aspen at Frias Properties — he owns inspection workflows, issue resolution, and unit readiness across a major portion of their 130-plus luxury vacation rental portfolio. Joined Frias in 2021 with deep luxury hospitality experience. Frias runs on Streamline for PMS and work orders, expanded into Snowmass in 2023, and won Best Property Management in Aspen three years running. Ben Wolff — who held Chris's exact role before being promoted to Managing Partner and GM in January 2024 — is the likely economic buyer above him. Strongest connection: Sam was just skiing Jackson Hole last month and works with PM operators in ski markets.

call_start.label: DIAL CHRIS LONGDEN
call_start.say: Calling Chris Longden — Director of Operations, East Aspen, Frias Properties.
call_start.note: Direct line: (970) 429-2436. Smile, take a breath, feet on the desk. You're calling a peer in the ski world, not pitching a stranger.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Chris — kinda random, but I was just out skiing Jackson Hole last month and ended up chatting with a couple property managers in ski towns about their turnover ops. When I started looking at the bigger luxury operators in Aspen, your name kept coming up at Frias. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye — have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Relaxed tone. Don't rush. Pause after 'tossed around' and let him respond. The skiing reference is real — Sam was at Jackson Hole in January 2026.

branches.label: Who is this? / What's this about?

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well usually we'd be working with someone in your seat. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let him talk. Whatever he says, bridge to discovery. Don't correct or re-pitch — just listen and follow the thread.

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — BRIDGE
heard_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well, reason for my call —
heard_no.note: Self-deprecating, light. Move right into the pain trigger without a long pause. This transition should feel seamless.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — I know mid-season is chaos over there. Would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again Thursday or Friday morning?
bad_timing.note: Don't grovel. Quick and specific. Mid-season acknowledgment shows you understand his world. If he gives a time, take it and get off the phone.

whos_this.label: CONFUSED OR GUARDED
whos_this.say: Yeah totally fair — it is a cold call, full transparency. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? You can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
whos_this.note: Disarm with honesty. Giving him permission to hang up paradoxically makes him more likely to listen. Keep your tone easy, not desperate.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED — LAST DITCH
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is this just not something you're focused on right now?
permission_rejected.note: Split the objection into multiple choice. If timing, you get a callback. If relevance, you learn something or exit clean. Don't push beyond this.

reschedule_set.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
reschedule_set.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Appreciate it, Chris. Talk soon.
reschedule_set.note: Get off the phone fast. Don't oversell the callback. Add it to your calendar the second you hang up.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I work with a few other ops directors at vacation rental companies pretty similar to you guys — 100-plus luxury units, high guest expectations, the whole thing. And the one thing I keep hearing is that their teams are taking hundreds of turnover photos every week, uploading them into Streamline or wherever, and nobody actually has time to look at them all. So stuff slips through — a stain on a sofa, a scratch on a countertop, a missing throw blanket — and it doesn't surface until a guest complains or an owner notices during their visit. And then it's your fire drill. Does that land at all, or is that totally off base for you guys?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after the question. This silence is the most important moment in the call. The Streamline mention shows homework without being heavy-handed. The specific items — stain, scratch, blanket — make it visceral. Let Chris react before you say another word.

branches.label: Yeah, that's real / shares their version
We've got a handle on that

warm_interest.label: THEY'RE WARM — STOP PITCHING
warm_interest.say: Yeah, I hear that a lot. So just so I'm not wasting your time — what does your inspection workflow actually look like right now after a cleaner finishes a unit?
warm_interest.note: STOP selling. Start asking. You are in discovery mode. Listen for: who reviews photos, how issues get flagged, what falls through the cracks, and where Streamline fits in their workflow chain.

branches.label: Mentions Streamline or their tech stack

discovery_process.label: DIG INTO THEIR PROCESS
discovery_process.say: Got it. And when something does slip through — a damage that wasn't caught before the next guest checks in — what does that usually look like? Is that coming back as a guest complaint, an owner calling, or a mix of both?
discovery_process.note: You're looking for the cost of misses. Guest complaints hurt reviews. Owner complaints hurt retention. Both hit Chris directly in his role as ops director.

discovery_streamline.label: STREAMLINE WORKFLOW
discovery_streamline.say: Oh nice — so you're running work orders through Streamline too. When a cleaner finishes a turn and the photos come in, is that something you're reviewing yourself, or does that sit more with the housekeeping team before it gets to you?
discovery_streamline.note: You know their housekeeping managers are Manuel Nava and Isidra Santos. If he names them, great — it confirms the chain. You're mapping where photos get stuck and who has the bottleneck.

discovery_season.label: SEASONAL VOLUME PRESSURE
discovery_season.say: Yeah, I bet — especially right now in the thick of ski season running back-to-back turns. How many units are you guys flipping on a heavy changeover day across East Aspen?
discovery_season.note: Get a number. Turnover volume equals photo volume equals the scale of the problem. This positions you as someone who actually understands the operational grind of a ski market.

discovery_consequences.label: CONSEQUENCES OF MISSES
discovery_consequences.say: And in a market like Aspen — where a single bad review on a luxury unit can actually move the needle — are you seeing that stuff hit guest reviews, or are you mostly catching it before it gets there?
discovery_consequences.note: Luxury market equals higher stakes per miss. This validates his world and adds urgency. If he admits it's hit reviews or owner relationships, that's a strong pain point to anchor the CTA on.

branches.label: Yes, it's affected reviews or owners
We mostly catch it in time

discovery_photo_review.label: PHOTO REVIEW BOTTLENECK
discovery_photo_review.say: Yeah, that's exactly what I keep hearing — the photos exist, the process is there, but the bandwidth to actually eyeball every single one just isn't realistic, especially mid-season. What if there was a way to have every photo automatically flagged for issues before the next guest walks in — without changing anything about how your team works today?
discovery_photo_review.note: This is the bridge from discovery to solution. One rhetorical question. Don't oversell. Pause and let him react. You're teeing up the one-sentence solution.

branches.label: Tell me more / how does that work?

solution_brief.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
solution_brief.say: So we built an AI layer that plugs into the photos your team's already taking — works with Streamline — and it automatically flags damage, missing items, staging issues, anything that's off. No new app for your cleaners, nothing changes about their day. We're already doing this for a company running about 600 properties on the East Coast. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
solution_brief.note: Streamline mention equals integration confidence. 600-property social proof is real traction. End with the soft CTA and PAUSE. Do not add more detail unless he specifically asks for it.

branches.label: I'd need to loop in Ben on this

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Look, I don't wanna burn your whole afternoon — especially mid-season. Would you be open to a 20-minute call where I can show you what this actually looks like with real turnover photos? Worst case you see what other luxury operators in ski markets are doing and steal some ideas.
cta_meeting.note: Low friction. Twenty minutes is digestible. 'Steal some ideas' frames the meeting as valuable even if they never buy. If he mentions the 2023 Snowmass expansion, reference it: 'especially with the growth into Snowmass.' PAUSE after the ask.

branches.label: I'd need to loop in Ben first

cta_soft.label: SOFT ASK — LUKEWARM
cta_soft.say: Totally get it — sounds like you guys run a tight ship. Honestly, the ops leaders who already have things dialed in are usually the ones who get the most out of what we do — they actually care about the details. Would you be open to a quick 20-minute look, even just to see what other luxury operators in ski markets are doing with AI on their turnover photos? Totally casual.
cta_soft.note: Reframe their competence as a reason TO look, not a reason to pass. 'Luxury operators in ski markets' is their exact peer group and creates healthy FOMO.

meeting_accepted.label: LOCK IN THE MEETING
meeting_accepted.say: Awesome. Let me grab my calendar — I've got next week pulled up. How does Tuesday or Wednesday afternoon look for you?
meeting_accepted.note: Give two specific day options. Get the day first, then narrow to a time. Do not say 'whenever works' — that never gets booked.

branches.label: Let me check and get back to you

book_time.label: MEETING BOOKED
book_time.say: Perfect — I'll shoot a calendar invite to clongden@friasproperties.com right now so it's locked in. It'll be me and my co-founder Rohan — he built the AI side, really sharp guy. Appreciate you taking my call, Chris. Talk soon.
book_time.note: Send the invite WHILE on the phone. Mention Rohan to set expectations for the demo. Then stop selling and get off the phone. You won.

book_pin_down.label: PIN IT DOWN
book_pin_down.say: Totally — I know mid-season is chaos. How about I throw a couple time slots on your calendar and you just accept whichever works? That way it doesn't slip through the cracks. Best email still clongden@friasproperties.com?
book_pin_down.note: Do not let 'I'll get back to you' become a dead end. Send calendar options now while you have momentum. Confirming the email keeps it concrete and actionable.

objection_not_interested.label: NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that inspections just aren't a pain point for you guys, or is it more that you just hate cold calls?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first — surprise him by not pushing back. Then split the objection with multiple choice. The humor in 'hate cold calls' usually gets a real answer and lowers the wall.

branches.label: Not a pain point / we're covered

split_not_interested_covered.label: THEY SAY THEY'RE COVERED
split_not_interested_covered.say: That's fair — with 130-plus units you'd have to have something dialed in. Out of curiosity, are you guys using any software for the photo review piece specifically, or is it more of a manual check by your team?
split_not_interested_covered.note: This surfaces their current tool or lack of one. If manual, that's your opening. If they name a tool, pivot to objection_have_process. The 130-plus unit count shows you know their scale.

branches.label: Does not want to engage further

objection_have_process.label: ALREADY HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with the scale you're running, you'd have to have something in place. This one's on me for not knowing that upfront. Just curious — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how it's working, or is it more that switching anything mid-season would just be a nightmare?
objection_have_process.note: Agree, then split. Mid-season is Frias-specific — it acknowledges their reality. Most people will admit the current process is not perfect when you give them a safe way to say it.

branches.label: Switching mid-season is the real issue

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Totally respect that — you're probably not buying anything right now, and I get it. But honestly, the ops leaders who end up making moves on stuff like this are usually the ones who already had it on their radar before budget opened up. Would you be open to a 20-minute look — not to buy anything, just so it's on your radar? Worst case you steal some ideas for what you're already doing.
sell_test_drive.note: Frame the meeting as intelligence-gathering, not a purchase decision. 'Steal some ideas' removes all pressure. This is your last real shot at getting a meeting — deliver it with confidence, not desperation.

sell_test_drive_seasonal.label: SEASONAL TIMING PLAY
sell_test_drive_seasonal.say: Hundred percent — nobody's ripping out a process in the middle of ski season, that'd be insane. What if we set something up for after things slow down — late April, early May? I could walk you through what we're seeing from other ski market operators and you'd have it in your back pocket heading into next season.
sell_test_drive_seasonal.note: Solve the timing objection by pushing the meeting to off-season. Zero pressure. Shows you understand their calendar. 'Heading into next season' creates a natural but soft deadline.

branches.label: Send me something and we'll see

objection_no_budget.label: NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it — nowadays it's hard enough to keep the tools you've got, let alone bring something new in. Just so I'm not barking up the wrong tree — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything new has to go through an approval process on your end?
objection_no_budget.note: Split the objection. If approval process, you likely need Ben Wolff — Managing Partner and GM who approves operational tooling. If cycle timing, sell a future meeting instead.

branches.label: Need approval / would go through Ben
Just not spending on new tools right now

objection_send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
objection_send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll send something over today. One quick question so it's not just another generic vendor email in your inbox — what would actually be useful for you to see? Is it more about how it plugs into Streamline, or more about what kind of stuff the AI actually catches on turnover photos?
objection_send_email.note: Accept immediately — do not resist. Then ask the tailoring question. This keeps him engaged one more beat and makes your follow-up email ten times more relevant. Note his answer carefully.

branches.label: Integration / how it works with Streamline

email_exit.label: EMAIL FOLLOW-UP SET
email_exit.say: Done — I'll get that over to clongden@friasproperties.com today. I'll drop in a couple times to connect next week in case you want to dig in after reading it. Appreciate your time, Chris.
email_exit.note: Confirm the email address. Include specific meeting time options in the follow-up email — do not ask permission, just include them. Send the email within the hour while the conversation is fresh.

referral_ben.label: LOOP IN BEN WOLFF
referral_ben.say: That makes sense — Ben would probably need to be in the loop on something like this, right? Would it make more sense to set up a quick call with both of you, or is it better if I reach out to him separately so I'm not creating extra work for you?
referral_ben.note: You know Ben Wolff is Managing Partner and GM — he held Chris's exact Director of Ops role before being promoted in Jan 2024. Do not pretend you don't know who he is. Let Chris lead on how to approach Ben.

branches.label: Set it up with both of us
Let me talk to him first

referral_get_ben_info.label: GET BEN'S DETAILS
referral_get_ben_info.say: Perfect — I've got his email as ben@friasproperties.com, is that still the best way to reach him? And would it help if I mention you and I chatted, or would you rather I keep it separate?
referral_get_ben_info.note: You already have Ben's email and direct line (970-429-2435) from research. Confirming the email is professional. The name-drop question is strategic — Chris's endorsement dramatically warms your outreach to Ben.

branches.label: Actually just set it up with both of us

referral_follow_up.label: CHRIS WILL TALK TO BEN
referral_follow_up.say: Totally get it — how about I shoot you a quick one-pager you can forward to Ben if it makes sense? And I'll check back with you next week to see where it landed. Sound fair?
referral_follow_up.note: Give him ammunition to share internally. The one-pager does your selling for you inside Frias. Set a specific follow-up window — next week — so it does not disappear into a black hole.

referral_exit.label: REFERRAL LOCKED
referral_exit.say: Really appreciate that, Chris. I'll reach out to Ben this week and keep you in the loop. Thanks for taking my call — talk soon.
referral_exit.note: Be genuinely grateful. Reach out to Ben within 24 hours. Reference Chris by name in the email to Ben. Add a calendar reminder to follow up with both.

graceful_exit.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand. If anything changes on your end, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Chris.
graceful_exit.note: Do not burn the bridge. Stay warm and brief. He might google you after hanging up. Log the call notes and set a 90-day follow-up reminder.

gatekeeper_initial.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_initial.say: Hey — could you get me through to Chris? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_initial.note: First name only for both you and Chris. No company name, no context, no explanation. Sound like you already know him. End with silence — let them act.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other property managers in the Aspen area on their inspection workflows. Would you mind letting Chris know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Dose information slowly. 'Property managers in Aspen' is true and relevant without sounding like a pitch. End with a redirect question — you ask the questions, you control the flow.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally understand — we help a couple property management companies with their turnover inspection workflows. I sent Chris a note about it. Would you mind giving him a heads up that I called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Do not fight the gatekeeper. Drop social proof, leave a trail, and exit gracefully. The 'sent a note' line implies prior contact and makes a follow-up call warmer.

gatekeeper_not_available.label: NOT AVAILABLE — LEAVE A TRAIL
gatekeeper_not_available.say: No worries — when's usually the best time to catch Chris, morning or afternoon? And if you could just let him know Sam Parks called, I'd really appreciate it. Thanks a bunch.
gatekeeper_not_available.note: Get a callback time window. Do not leave a detailed message through the gatekeeper. Having your name dropped before you call back warms the next attempt significantly.

voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL
voicemail.say: Hey Chris, it's Sam Parks — I work with a few property managers in ski markets on their turnover inspection workflows and your name came up as someone I should talk to over at Frias. Was hoping to grab you for a quick minute. I'll try you again, but feel free to reach me at [your number] if that's easier. Thanks.
voicemail.note: Keep it under 20 seconds. Do not pitch. Do not say AI. Just enough to be intriguing without sounding like a vendor. Try calling again in two days if no response.
